DOC.HEAD: New Covenant House Leader Says Shelter Deserves Second Chance
DOC.TEXT: The new leader of the troubled Covenant House says the youth shelter deserves a second chance. ``The need is still there,'' Sister Mary Rose McGeady said in Sunday's editions of the Daily News. She told the newspaper that it will be difficult to persuade donors to give money to the charity that has been rocked by sexual and financial scandals, resulting in a loss of $12 million in donations this year. Despite the scandals, kids keep showing up a the shelter. ``We are still seeing between 30 to 60 new kids every day,'' she said. To help restore confidence in the charity, she plans to invite potential donors to Covenant House. She also has sent donors a copy of an internal report about the improprieties. The Rev. Bruce Ritter, the charity's founder and main fund-raiser, resigned earlier this year amid allegations of financial misdeeds and that he had sexual relationships with several male youths staying at the shelter.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Attack House of Vice President's Mother, Kill Policeman
DOC.TEXT: Maoist Shining Path guerrillas attacked the house of the mother of Vice President Maximo San Roman, killing a policeman, authorities said Saturday. Three other policemen were shot and wounded in the attack Friday night in the Andean city of Cuzco, 350 miles southeast of the capital. The vice president's mother, Rebecca de San Roman, was unhurt. Police said about six rebels tossed sticks of dynamite at the doorway of the house and opened fire on the stunned policemen. San Roman, one of Peru's two vice presidents, took office July 28 along with President Alberto Fujimori. In other violence, two rebels were killed in a shootout between an army patrol and a guerrilla column south of Huancayo, a mountain city 120 miles east of Lima. Police said an unknown number of rebels were wounded in the firefight, in the Pasos district 15 miles south of Huancayo. No soldiers were wounded, police said. The 30-minute gun battle began when the army patrol came upon about 15 rebels trying to blow up an electrical substation, police said. In Ayacucho, a rebel stronghold 230 miles southeast of Lima, two rebels shot and killed a maid on Friday. A note found on the maid's body said ``This is how squeelers die.'' Almost 20,000 Peruvians have died in political violence in the 10 years since the Shining Path first took up arms.

DOC.HEAD: Former Federal EOC Chief Discloses Local Income Tax Irregularity
DOC.TEXT: Eleanor Holmes Norton, a former Carter administration official and the front-runner in a campaign for the District of Columbia's non-voting congressional seat, disclosed Saturday that she and her husband failed to file local income tax returns for eight years. The Georgetown University law professor said in a written statement that she learned Saturday ``for the first time'' that the 1982 through 1989 tax returns she signed were never mailed by her husband. She blamed the failure on ``procrastination'' and a dispute with the city over the amount of the tax. ``I love and trust him and realize that his lack candor resulted from understandable reluctance to admit to his procrastination,'' she said in a statement. ``The situation is all the more tragic because our income has at all times been more than ample to pay any taxes due.'' Norton's husband, Edward Norton, is a lawyer and former chairman of the D.C. board of Elections and Ethics. The candidate herself was chief of the U.S. Employment Opportunity Commission under President Carter. The disclosure about the unfiled returns follows Norton's admission Friday that she owes about $25,000 in city taxes. She said she and her husband would pay the city $25,381.90 they owed as of Jan. 18 1990. The sum stems from a protracted dispute between the Nortons and the city over $10,755 in income taxes the couple failed to pay in 1982. The additional amount comes from interest and penalties.

DOC.HEAD: Parks Returns to Miss America Pageant, Croons ``There She Is''
With AM-Miss America
DOC.TEXT: Bert Parks returned to the Miss America Pageant Saturday night after a 10-year break to serenade 29 former Miss Americas with a lip-synched ``There She Is.'' But Parks, 75, neglected to mention at least a dozen of the former winners he was supposed to introduce. Mouthing his trademark song over a recording of his own voice, he appeared to get out of synch. He returned to the stage at the end to congratulate the winner, Miss Illinois Marjorie Judith Vincent. Parks, who was fired in 1980 as pageant emcee by pageant officials who felt he was too old, received a standing ovation of 15 seconds when he first walked onstage. Former pageant director Al Marks, who died last year, fired Parks before the 1980 pageant, saying he was too old at age 65 to continue performing. Parks went on to emcee other pageants ranging from a tugboat competition to contests judging small dogs. His firing generated nationwide sympathy and a letter-writing campaign organized by Johnny Carson. Parks' return to the Miss America stage Saturday night began with an on-stage invitation from actor Gary Collins, who is the pageant's co-host along with Miss America 1971 Phyllis George. ``I thought you would never ask,'' Parks boomed in an offstage voice as he rose from a front row seat in the audience and bounced onto the stage to applause. ``I never thought you'd answer,'' said Collins.

DOC.HEAD: Rocket Blaze Victim Identified as Safety Worker Crushed by Crane
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with details of accident, victim's job description, cause unknown, fresh quote. EDITS. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `A section...' Rainney in 2nd graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: The man killed when part of Titan 4 rocket erupted in flames after falling from a 400-foot crane was a safety worker crushed under the collapsing crane, officials said Saturday. Alan M. Quimby, 27, of Lancaster was one of the workers overseeing the movement of the solid fuel rocket motor Friday when the crane fell 70 feet and slid another 70 down a concrete-covered hill, said Rainney Adams, spokesman for the Air Force Astronautics Laboratory. Quimby was crushed by falling boxes of sand and gravel used as counter weights to balance the crane, Adams said. Nine other people were injured. The cause of the collapse was unknown. ``It could be a very long-term investigation. We'd be remiss in speculating until we found the cause,'' Adams said. A section of the 112-foot rocket booster ignited on impact when it fell while being maneuvered toward an outdoor test stand, Maj. Dick Cole said. Titan 4s, built by Martin Marietta Corp., are considered the Air Force's primary booster for launching heavy payloads, particularly intelligence satellites. It is the nation's most powerful unmanned rocket. The fire sent a cloud billowing over the base, but toxic hydrogen chloride was released in amounts too small to endanger anyone in the sparsely populated area, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Lands Safely in Guam After Part of Engine Covering Falls Off
DOC.TEXT: A Continental Air Micronesia DC-10 raining debris after liftoff turned back and landed safely Saturday. Flight 1967, bound for Saipan and Tokyo, was carrying 133 passengers when a witness called the airline to report pieces falling from the jetliner, Contintal Air Micronesia spokesman Guy Schroeder said. ``We discovered a piece missing from the left-hand No. 2 engine fan cawl _ it's a curved piece of metal that covers the rear engine,'' Schroeder said. ``It is substantially gone.'' Schroeder said the missing piece measured about 4 feet by 8 feet. The airline learned of the problem about six minutes after takeoff and landed safely less than an hour later. The engine continued to function without the cover and there were no reports of injuries from falling debris. Ed Guzman said he recovered a 3-foot-by-1-foot piece of metal and took it to the Continental desk at Guam International Airport. ``We put the piece on the counter and said, `This came off one of your planes,' and the lady didn't believe me,'' Guzman said. Schroeder said the cause of the problem was under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Miss Illinois Crowned Miss America 1991
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 15-16 with history of black pageant winners. Minor editing in 17th graf. Picks up 17th graf pvs, `The other...
DOC.TEXT: Miss Illinois Marjorie Judith Vincent, a pianist of Haitian descent who wants to practice international law, was crowned Miss America 1991 early Sunday. Miss Vincent broke into tears and smiled brightly as she given a suprise serenade of ``There She Is'' by Bert Parks, who returned to the pageant 10 years after he was fired as emcee. ``I couldn't believe it,'' she said afterward. ``I was just so happy that I was in the Top 10. I still don't believe it.'' Asked what she would do next, Miss Vincent said, ``I have no idea. I just want to see my family.'' First runner-up was Miss South Carolina Mary Waddell Gainey, 24, of Hartsville. Following her as second runner-up was Miss Tennessee Dana Brown, 25, of Memphis. Miss Texas Suzanne Lawrence, 21, of Humble was third runner-up. And Miss Louisiana Linnea Marie Fayard, 22, of Shreveport took fifth place. Earlier in the pageant, the 75-year-old Parks serenaded 29 former Miss Americas with a lip-synched ``There She Is'' that wasn't quite synched. A standing ovation greeted Parks, who neglected to mention at least a dozen of the former beauty queens he was to introduce. Miss Vincent, 25, of Oak Park, is a third-year law student at Duke University who graduated from DePaul University in 1988 with a degree in music. She played Chopin's ``Fantasy Impromptu _ Opus 66'' with dramatic flourishes and a light touch during the talent portion of the competition. The 5-foot-6, 110-pound Miss Vincent performed in a rust satin embroidered coat detailed in gold cracked ice over a black sheath petticoat dress. She wore a turquoise chiffon silk gown that was beaded with silver, white and varying shades of turquoise bugle beads, sequins and rhinestones. The gown also featured a sweetheart neckline with a keyhole opening in the back. Miss Vincent, who came to the United States from Haiti when she was 3 years old, has said she wants to study international law and help in the economic development of the impoverished Caribbean nation. She speaks French and creole. Miss Vincent comes from a modest family. Her father is a doorman and a check cashier and her mother is a seamstress. She said in a pre-pageant interview that she wants to speak out on the plight of battered women. Miss Vincent was the only black contestant among the 50 this year. Last year's Miss America, Debbye Turner, also is black. Miss Vincent is the fourth black woman to hold the title. Vanessa Williams, then Miss New York, was the first in 1983. She lost the crown because nude photos taken years earlier appeared in Penthouse magazine. She was replaced by first runner-up Suzette Charles, Miss New Jersey, who also is black. Among her interests, Miss Vincent lists listening to chamber music and jazz, collecting mugs, cooking, reading mysteries and romance novels. The other semifinalists were Miss Colorado Karrie Mitchell, 24; Miss Iowa Kerri Lynne Rosenberg, 26; Miss Oklahoma Cynthia Lynne White, 24; Miss Pennsylvania Marla Wynne, 23, and Miss Virginia Shannon Noelle DePuy, 19. They scored the highest after three nights of preliminary competitions in swimsuit, talent, evening gown and interviews with judges. Miss South Carolina, like Miss Turner, played the marimba. Miss Pennsylvania performed a ventriloquist act with a green cockatoo puppet named Oscar. Several of the contestants overcame personal tragedies and disabilities to make it to the Boardwalk. Miss Texas recovered from cervical cancer last year and also controversy this year surrounding the head of the state pageant, who has faced allegations he made sexist remarks to contestants. Miss Pensylvania has lost 11 family members to cancer. Miss South Carolina went through six operations to correct four birth defects, including a collapsible urethra and a lack of a hip socket. The pageant axed Parks in 1980 as master of ceremonies, saying he was too old for the program at age 65. Gary Collins and Miss America 1971 Phyllis George served as co-hosts of the show. Despite the nostalgic appeal of Parks and the former Miss Americas, the pageant has continued taking small steps away from its image as a beauty contest. Pageant director Leonard Horn banned pre-pageant week photos of contestants in swimsuits, but the swimsuit competition remains in the contest because the ratings-conscious pageant believes viewers would rebel if it were eliminated. For a second straight year, contestants selected platforms they would like to emphasize during their reign. Most chose safe issues such as illiteracy, education and elderly care. Miss Turner, 24, of Mexico, Mo., plans to return to the University of Missouri-Columbia School of Veterinary Medicine where she is six months short of her degree. The pageant generates more than $5 million in scholarship money for the estimated 80,000 women between the ages of 18 and 26 who compete at the local, state and national level. The new Miss America receives a $35,000 scholarship and makes appearances throughout the year that Miss Turner guesses netted her more than $200,000. The first runner-up receives $20,000; the second runner-up $14,000; the third runner-up $11,000; and the fourth runner-up $8,000. The other five semifinalists receive $6,000 and the other 40 contestants get $2,500 apiece. In determining the winner, interviews conducted during the week count for 30 percent; the Saturday evening talent competition counts for 40 percent; and the Saturday night swimsuit and evening gown competitions were each 15 percent. Chosen for the celebrity panel were actresses Delta Burke, Shirley Jones, Nell Carter and Cynthia Sikes; talk show host Larry King; actor John Forsythe; and author Sidney Sheldon. Ms. Burke was Miss Florida 1974 and Ms. Sikes was Miss Kansas 1972.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Says Iraq `Loves Peace;' More Americans Arrive in Jordan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with plane arriving in Frankfurt; Pickup 4th, `Saddam in...'; SUBS 23-25 pvs, `A U.S....would arrive' to conform; Pickup 26th, `Future charter...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DOD1, DOD2, DHA1, NY23, NY28
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's Saddam Hussein on Saturday urged Presidents Bush and Gorbachev on the eve of their summit to get out of the Persian Gulf crisis and let the Arab world settle the matter. A U.S.-chartered flight carrying about 300 Americans from Kuwait and Iraq meanwhile, landed in Frankfurt, West Germany early Sunday and, after refueling, was to continue on to Charleston, S.C. The plane arrived from Amman, Jordan. Saddam, in a statement read by an announcer on Iraqi television and billed as an open message to the U.S. and Soviet leaders, told them: ``I am not saying to either of you ... what your decision should be.'' But he said Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev should bear in mind that ``Iraq's army did not invade either of your countries.'' Saddam, whose Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait set off the chain of events leading to the summit in Helsinki, Finland, described Iraq as a peace-loving nation and warned of dangers of the huge U.S.-led buildup of forces in the gulf region. ``God and history are witness ... that the foreign intervention is complicating matters and will not provide a settlement,'' he said. In Helsinki, Bush and Gorbachev expressed hopes for a settlement to the Persian Gulf crisis, now in its sixth week. Bush told reporters on arrival he hoped the summit would ``strengthen our common approach to this unjustifiable act of aggression.'' The Soviet president, arriving later, cited the ``acute crisis'' in the gulf. ``I hope this meeting will be successful,'' he said. Bush's National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft suggested that the prospect of U.S.-Soviet unity on the Persian Gulf has Saddam on the run. ``We hope it causes him to lose some sleep,'' Scowcroft told reporters after a Saturday evening working dinner in Bush's hotel suite. ``We've put together a strategy that has a good chance of success without the use of military force,'' Scowcroft said, referring to the trade embargo against Iraq. Asked whether Saddam was backing off, Scowcroft said, ``I think he's maneuvering at present ... looking for a way out of his dilemma.'' Iraq, meanwhile, sought to solidify its new rapprochement with Iran in an effort to get around U.N. economic sanctions. Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz is due in Tehran on Sunday for the first high-level visit in a decade. Tehran's Jomhuri Islami newspaper said in an editorial that Aziz would return to Iraq ``with his hands full'' if Iraq continues its conciliatory policy toward Iran. This policy has included Iraq's withdrawal of troops from Iranian territory, its exchange of war prisoners, and its dropping of a long-standing demand for full control of a strategic waterway. In Kuwait, two more embassies bowed to the pressure brought to bear by the Iraqi occupiers. Sweden and Norway evacuated their diplomatic staffs but insisted their missions technically remained open. The Iraqis, who ordered embassies in the conquered emirate to close two weeks ago, have been backing up that demand with a cutoff of food, water, power and telephone service to the missions. About 20 embassies, including the U.S. mission, remain open with skeleton staffs to symbolize their refusal to accept Iraq's annexation of Kuwait, and to try to provide some protection for their citizens trapped by the invasion. About 2,200 Americans remain in Iraq and Kuwait, U.S. officials estimate, and some men among them have been placed at important installations to deter possible Western attacks. Women and children are being allowed to leave. A U.S.-chartered Iraqi Airways flight from Kuwait to Amman on Friday carried 165 Americans, most of them women and children, and a few other foreigners. A second flight, carrying 130 Americans, left Kuwait on Saturday, with a stopover in Baghdad, U.S. Embassy sources in Amman said. The entire group was flown to Frankfurt early Sunday aboard a Northwest Airlines plane and after a brief stopover was to fly on to Charleston, S.C. Future charter flights were unlikely to be routed through the Jordanian capital. Iraq said Saturday that charters would no longer fly to Amman, although they could travel to other points. That appeared to be acceptable to U.S. officials. A State Department spokesman said on condition of anonymity a U.S.-chartered flight would leave Baghdad on Sunday for London. Friday's flight was the first U.S.-chartered airlift out of Kuwait. Other departing Americans have had to make their way out in desert convoys. The Norwegian and Swedish diplomats who left their embassies in Kuwait on Saturday were traveling overland to Baghdad, where an uncertain fate awaited them. It was not clear whether the Iraqi government would let them leave. Male diplomats and dependents who left the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait have been prevented from leaving. In Cairo, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak met with Secretary of State James A. Baker III and urged the United States and Soviet Union to coordinate their actions in the gulf crisis. ``I hope that Gorbachev and Bush have one line for dealing with this problem,'' said the normally circumspect Mubarak, ``because it will be a hell of a problem in this area if there are differences.'' Baker said Washington and Cairo agree that the crisis cannot be solved without total Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait and restoration of the Kuwaiti government deposed in the invasion. About 100,000 U.S. troops are dug into the Saudi desert and aboard ships in the gulf region, facing an estimated 260,000 Iraqi soldiers in and around Kuwait. Mubarak indicated more Egyptian troops would be deployed in the gulf region but gave no details. In other developments: _ A Columbus, Ga., woman identified her son as the American wounded by Iraqi troops while trying to avoid capture in Kuwait. The State Department had refused to identify the American shot Thursday. Mrs. Cullen Hoffman, who would not give her first name, identified the American as her son, 33-year-old Miles Hoffman, a financial analyst and investor for the Kuwaiti government. She said she did not know her son's condition. _ One pilot was hospitalized and a second escaped unhurt when a U.S. army helicopter crashed during a night training mission, U.S. military spokesmen said Saturday. It was the second such crash in two days. _ In London, Britain's Department of Trade and Industry announced it will allow the export of medicine to Iraq and Kuwait. A department spokesman said such exports were permitted on humanitarian grounds under the U.N. Security Council resolution imposing a trade embargo on Iraq and Kuwait.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs with Gorbachev comment after first meeting, picks up 3rd graf pvs, 'When Gorbachev
DOC.HEAD: Saddam Tops Summit Agenda for Bush and Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev held their hastily scheduled summit today, searching for ways to forge an even closer alliance in the international effort to isolate Iraq's Saddam Hussein. At a break midway through the scheduled five hours of talks, Gorbachev told reporters, ``It was a good conversation.'' But the Soviet leader refused to divulge details, saying they would answer questions later at a joint news conference wrapping up the one-day summit. Bush, too, waved off questions as they posed for photos with Finnish President Mauno Koivisto and their wives. ``You heard what the man said,'' said Bush, before heading off to lunch with their host and his wife. Bush arrived first for the talks at Finland's Presidential Palace, arranged just eight days ago against the backdrop of the gulf crisis. It was the third Bush-Gorbachev summit in the past nine months. When Gorbachev stepped into the palace's yellow salon, Bush greeted him with a handshake and said, ``How are you, sir? I look forward to the meeting.'' Gorbachev gave Bush a large, framed cartoon depicting the two leaders as champion boxers, with a fallen figure representing the Cold War at their feet. The referee's head was a globe. The Russian caption read, ``Knockout punch!'' Bush laughed and said, ``That's wonderful.'' A reporter asked the Soviet leader in Russian if he was optimistic. ``Yes, and tomorrow, too,'' replied Gorbachev. The two leaders briefly stepped out onto a balcony behind a bulletproof shield, drawing applause from a crowd of 300 people gathered in Market Square in front of the palace. As a light rain fall on the misty morning, a woman in the crowd sang ``We Shall Overcome'' in English. ``Much is at stake'' at Sunday's hastily arranged summit, Bush said before his third meeting as president with the Soviet leader. Iraq's five-week occupation of Kuwait and its treatment of foreign hostages dominated the agenda as the two leaders prepared for five hours of face-to-face meetings, a lunch and a joint news conference. And, while neither side gave any indication that a major new initiative would emerge, both leaders seemed ready to renew pressure on Saddam to withdraw from Kuwait. White House officials hinted late Saturday that the two leaders may decide to issue a joint statement on the Persian Gulf crisis. Several other subjects are likely to be discussed, including a possible swap of U.S. oil-delivery technology for more Soviet oil and a more sympathetic U.S. ear for Western economic aid for Moscow. In Saudi Arabia, a diplomatic source said Gorbachev came to Helsinki prepared to offer the Soviet maritime fleet to the United States to transport equipment to the Gulf and to withdraw Soviet advisers from Iraq. The month-old U.S. military deployment has been handicapped by the lack of sealift for materiel. And while the Bush administration would like to see the Soviet advisers pulled out, it has been low-key on the issue. Both leaders were upbeat about the session, which puts the two superpowers on the same side of a major international issue for the first time since World War II. ``We'll be speaking, not to some adversary, but to the leader of a country with whom I think we're going to have increasingly productive relations,'' Bush said on Saturday. Gorbachev, arriving in the Finnish capital Saturday evening, said it was necessary ``to discuss the acute crisis in the Persian Gulf and a number of other issues.'' For Gorbachev, joining the United States' condemnation of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and supporting the full naval blockade sanction by the United Nations is a sensitive matter. Moscow has long been Baghdad's principal arms supplier and has enjoyed a special relationship with the Iraqi government. Gorbachev must also be careful not to offend the already restive Moslem population in Central Asia. En route to the summit, Bush said he did not plan to ask Gorbachev to contribute ground forces to the U.S.-led military buildup along Iraq's border with Saudi Arabia _ even though high-ranking U.S. officials have said such assistance would be helpful. Both leaders arrived under overcast skies and received matching red-carpet greetings from Finnish President Mauno Koivisto, who had lunch with Bush and dinner with Gorbachev. It was a working summit for both leaders and they did little in the way of recreation or sightseeing. Security was extremely tight, as always, and Soviet, American and Finnish flags were flown together. Crowds lined the streets as the U.S. and Soviet motorcades passed by and people forked over $20 for T-shirts with the faces of Bush and Gorbachev superimposed on that of Saddam. Except for a brief stop to shake hands in a downtown Helsinki market district and a short visit to the U.S. embassy, Bush spent much of his time in his hotel suite meeting with advisers. White House officials said the administration would have no reaction to Saddam's six-point message to both leaders. It was not clear whether Bush watched the address, broadcast on Cable News Network and available to him in his hotel suite. Bush was also to meet on Sunday with a trade mission of U.S. business executives here on their way to Moscow. The two leaders last met in Washington in early June. Their first summit was at Malta last December.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Dials 911 With Nose, Rescued from Gas-filled Home
DOC.TEXT: A woman saved herself by dialing for help with her nose after an intruder tied her up, turned on the gas in her stove and left a candle burning, apparently in hope of triggering an explosion, authorities said. Police said they were hunting for the person who attacked the 37-year-old woman early Thursday and seemed to want to make certain she died. ``He shut the windows when he left, and he shut the door behind him when he left. And he did light a candle in the living room, where the victim was,'' said Detective Alan Keiser. Police did not release the victim's name. After breaking into the woman's home, the man tied her hands in back of her and fastened to a chair, police said. He then ransacked the house, turned on the gas in the oven without lighting it, closed the windows, lit the candle and left. But the victim was able to tip her chair over to the floor, grab the telephone with her teeth and dial 911 with her nose, police said. The victim was taken to Denver General Hospital for treatment of exposure to natural gas. There were no arrests as of early Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Training Before Dawn, By The Light of the Moon
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The 265th Quartermaster Detachment of the South Carolina National Guard is one of the reserve units called up for possible duty in Saudi Arabia. National Writer Fred Bayles is following the 14 Guardsmen as they prepare for deployment overseas.

The waning moon is still the brightest object in the morning sky as the men from the 265th Quartermaster Detachment turn into the homestretch of their daily run. The rest of this huge Army post just now is shrugging awake. Diesels crank over at the motor pool. Shouts of other groups doing calisthenics come from different directions. But the 265th, a South Carolina National Guard unit training for the Mideast, is finishing its hour of PT _ physicial training. The men have chanted cadence about whiskey, women and dying in the drop zone. Now something else is needed to get them back to the barracks. ``TWO-SIX-FIVE,'' calls the captain leading the heavy breathing troop. ``TWO-SIX-FIVE,'' they answer in unison. The pace picks up; the barracks is a quarter mile away. But the captain orders a turn and, with a chorus of groans, the group doubles around to pick up stragglers. ``More PT,'' some of the men gasp. ``Please sir, more PT!'' Like many facets of military training, the 6 a.m. run has multiple purposes. It conditions civilian bodies and minds. It acclimates men for the desert. And it reinforces the idea of unity. The 265th is a tiny National Guard unit from Allendale, S.C., that specializes in water purification. Yet over 11 days, the group has trained for everything but that. The men, whose civilian jobs range from prison guard to college student, have drilled over and over on radio communications, weapons, chemical warfare and field operations. ``These guys are probably going to be far back behind the lines, but water is one of the most important things over there,'' said Capt. Robert Appiah, the regular Army officer supervising the 265th's training. ``That makes them a target and we have to prepare them for that,'' he said. But the constant training and the debilitating heat and humidity of southern Georgia have taken a toll in the group, which has an average age of 35. Several of the men hobble around with bad knees and pulled muscles. One went to sick call suffering from mild dehydration. Sgt. Earnest Deloach was excused from PT for two weeks to give a damaged hamstring time to heal. But he was out on the road the next morning trying to keep up. When he began to fall behind, he was ordered to drop out. ``I'll finish it, Sarge,'' he called. He did finish, limping into the barracks area as the other men were finishing their showers. Deloach, who has spent 18 of his 38 years in the Guard, is a big, jolly man whose tight-fitting helmet looks like it was screwed onto his head. When he laughs, which is often, his big body shakes with mirth. When he gets excited or angry, his voice climbs several octaves. Now a supervisor at the Allendale Correctional Institution, Deloach used to travel the country as a lineman, stringing wire for power and cable systems. ``I quit because I was away from home too much. I got tired of all that traveling,'' he said. ``Now look at me, here I go again, 10,000 miles.'' Like the other men, Deloach tries to balance his duty with the problems it causes his personal life, like missing his son's 16th birthday last week. During a briefing about conduct for troops in Saudi Arabia, someone asks what they can bring back with them from overseas duty. ``There's only one damned thing I want to bring home,'' Deloach said with annoyance. ``That's the head of Saddam Hussein.''

DOC.HEAD: Education Goals Set, Now for the Hard Part
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Terry Branstad of Iowa was asked whether President Bush and the nation's governors had set education goals that were impossible to achieve. His response: a chuckle. ``Look,'' Branstad said. ``What did you want us to say _ that `U.S. students will be third, fourth or fifth in the world in mathematics and science achievement by the year 2000?''' The exchange at a recent CBS News education conference reflects a growing concern that the goals approved in February after an education summit between the president and governors may be a bit too lofty. The goals say that beginning in the year 2000: _All children will start school ready to learn. _High school graduations will increase to at least 90 percent. _Students will demonstrate competency over challenging subject matter. _Students will be first in the world in math and science. _Every adult American will be literate. _Every school will be free of violence and drugs. The goals are set against a backdrop of dismal statistics. The Children's Defense Fund notes that every eight seconds a student drops out, every 67 seconds a teenager has a baby, every 7 minutes a child is arrested for drugs and every year 700,000 students graduate who cannot read their diplomas. ``The issue of having all children come to school ready to learn is almost breathtaking in its implications,'' said Ernest Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching. He said the concept includes making sure pregnant women receive adequate prenatal care and children get good nutrition and health care. ``If we would deliver on that, I am confident all the others would fall into place much more completely,'' Boyer said. He said the pledge ``really brings the issue of commitment to children front and center.'' Asked about the chances of attaining the math goal, educator Marilyn Burns of Sausalito, Calif., quipped: ``Is this a probability question? What, did Jimmy the Greek give this one?'' ``I do believe this is a window of opportunity,'' said Burns, who has created special math training courses. ``I have to believe that futility is better than apathy. It's only going to happen if we make it happen,'' she said. ``It takes all of us to save the system.'' The Education Department said 19 percent of all eighth graders and 30 percent of Hispanics, blacks, and American Indians were not proficient in the basic math skills considered necessary to perform everyday tasks. About 12 percent of the 29.5 million students entering the 57,000 public elementary schools this fall will attend remedial reading programs and 6 percent will go to similar programs for extra help in math, said the National Association of Elementary School Principals. Congressional statistics show that four-fifths of elementary school mathematics teachers are not fully qualified to teach math and two-thirds of elementary school science teachers are not fully qualified. A third of American high schools offer no physics course, and many others offer no chemistry course. U.S. high school seniors ranked ninth in advanced physics in a survey of 13 countries and 11th in advanced chemistry. American students were last in advanced biology. The science goal ``was the president's and governors' statement,'' said Timothy Goldsmith, biology professor at Yale University. He sought to separate himself from that view but said the statement raises questions about the objective of science education. ``If the task seems gargantuan, consider recent history,'' said AT&T Chairman Robert E. Allen. ``A curtain of iron and a wall of stone crumbled in the face of an ideal. Let us keep that picture before us. For if freedom can topple walls, surely a belief in children can build effective classrooms.'' Edward Ahnert, incoming head of the Exxon Education Foundation, added that the goal will serve a useful purpose by ``mobilizing the hundreds of thousands of people that it's going to require to do what we want to do.'' ``If by the year 2000, we have moved from (a low ranking) up to second or third _ we're not No. 1 _ have we failed?'' asked Ahnert. ``It's not getting to be No. 1 that's nearly so important as getting to be much better than we are. ``So if Japan or whoever it is is still No. 1 and we're No. 2 _ it's still a hell of a lot better than being 14th or 15th.''

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Stage Another Attack In Corsica
DOC.TEXT: Five masked gunmen blew up a villa at a southern housing development Sunday after tying up 14 residents, police said. It was the second such bombing in two days. No one was injured, and there was no immediate claim of responsibility in either incident. But previous attacks have been launched by separatist guerrillas who oppose tourist development on this French Mediterranean island. In the latest incident, the gunmen tied up occupants of two homes and placed explosives in each building late Saturday, police said. One of the charges did not go off, and the other exploded after midnight, causing severe damage, according to police. On Friday, gunmen tied up 29 Italian vacationers and workmen at a partially built tourist complex, then blew up two bungalows and a construction crane.

DOC.HEAD: Price Of Champagne Grapes Up 20 Percent
DOC.TEXT: High prices for champagne lie ahead as farmers prepare to launch the annual grape harvest Tuesday. A dispute between growers and champagne producers ended in April with the collapse of a 30-year system that fixed an overall price for grapes each season. The price has since risen by 20 percent, to about $3 a pound. There is usually a two-year gap between the grapes' harvest and their sale for champagne production, but producers say the price of a bottle of champagne could rise by 10 percent or more as early as January 1991. Last year, 249 million bottles of champagne were sold worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Teresa Calls Her Re-Election God's Plan
DOC.TEXT: Mother Teresa, whose wish to retire was rejected by nuns from around the world, said Sunday her re-election as head of her charity was part of God's ``own plans.'' The balloting was to have been a vote to choose a successor to the frail, 80-year-old nun who is known as the ``saint of the gutters'' for her work with the destitute and the poor. ``I was expecting to be free, but God has his own plans,'' Mother Teresa said when she met reporters for the first time after Saturday's election. The Nobel Peace Prize laureate withdrew her decision to step down as superior general of the Missionaries of Charity after ballots were cast by 103 delegates summoned from missions around the globe. Calcutta's Vicar General Monsignor Francis Gomes, who presided over the secret balloting, said Mother Teresa had little choice but to accept the unanimous vote. Mother Teresa said she had been firm on stepping down _ until the balloting forced her to change her decision. ``These things cannot be decided beforehand,'' she said. In March, Pope John Paul II said he was bowing to Mother Teresa's wish to retire from the top post of the order she founded. He had rejected her earlier requests to step aside. Mother Teresa suffered a nearly fatal heart attack a year ago. She returned to work but asked for retirement within a few months. Asked if she would slow down her pace of work, Mother Teresa replied: ``We have sisters who are capable of helping.'' But she said she would continue to travel according to the needs of her group. Along with Mother Teresa, four aides were elected. Sister Fredrick, a Maltese nun who previously was head of the charity's U.S. chapter based in Washington, was elected as Mother Teresa's deputy. Mother Teresa was elected to a further six-year term. The Yugoslav-born Roman Catholic nun began her work in earnest for the poor and helpless 43 years ago in the gutters of Calcutta, India's most densely populated city in the eastern state of West Bengal. Mother Teresa gave up a comfortable teaching job at a Catholic school to set up a series of homes for the dying in Calcutta and eventually throughout the world. Today, the Missionaries of Charity operate 430 homes in 95 countries for lepers, cripples, abandoned babies and others with no place to turn. Mother Teresa was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Improves Chances for Tougher Standards, Supporters Say
DOC.TEXT: Proponents of legislation to require the U.S. auto fleet to average 40 miles per gallon insist they are gaining momentum as the Persian Gulf crisis focuses new attention on the nation's dependence on foreign oil. The Senate bill, which opponents claim could force Americans to give up the convenience of big cars and minivans, is expected to reach the Senate floor this week. It cleared the Commerce Committee on a 14-4 vote in April. An environmental lobbyist said supporters are within two or three votes of the 60 needed to thwart an expected filibuster. He said the bill is a weapon to use against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, whose invasion of Kuwait and threat to Saudi oil fields precipitated the latest Middle East crisis. ``It's the single biggest step we can take to curb Saddam Hussein's power,'' said Dan Becker of the Sierra Club. ``If we don't need his oil, it lowers our stakes in the Middle East.'' Prior to the Iraqi invasion, the bill's primary selling point was supporters' contention that it would curb carbon dioxide emissions, which are believed to be a major contributor to global warming. The automobile industry is mounting a full-scale lobbying effort against the measure, which is sponsored by Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev. The Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association, which represents the Big Three U.S. automakers, is purchasing full-page advertisements in major newspapers to argue its case. An industry spokesman acknowledged that the job of defeating the bill in the Senate, already difficult, had become tougher since Iraq invaded Kuwait last month, prompting a United Nations economic boycott and deployment of U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia. ``It's going to be tough because there is an effort to portray the Bryan bill as a positive reaction to the Middle East situation,'' said Tim McCarthy of the manufacturers group. But he said prospects of the bill getting through the House are slim even if it passes the Senate and he noted that the Bush administration strongly opposes the measure. The administration has urged motorists to drive the speed limit and keep their tires properly inflated to save fuel. Congress established fuel economy standards in 1975 in response to the 1973 Arab oil embargo. At that time, the average U.S.-made car got 12 mpg. Under current law, new car fleets _ all the cars a company manufactures in a given year _ must get an overall average of at least 27.5 miles per gallon. The Bryan bill would require each manufacturer to improve its corporate average fuel economy, or CAFE, 20 percent by 1995 and 40 percent by 2001. The overall fleet average would be about 34.4 mpg in 1995 and 40.2 mpg by 2001, Bryan says. ``This higher CAFE can save us 2.8 million barrels of oil a day,'' Bryan said Friday. Half of the nation's oil consumption _ 16.9 million barrels a day _ is imported. About 63 percent of the nation's oil goes to transportation, mainly the 180 million cars, trucks and buses on U.S. highways. Automakers say the Bryan bill would have no impact on the current crisis because the fuel savings would not materialize for 10 years to 15 years. Fuel efficiency has doubled since the 1970s, partly because the average car's weight fell from 4,000 pounds to 3,000 pounds, McCarthy said. The Bryan bill's standards are not technologically feasible without another round of ``downsizing,'' which would eliminate many larger models, he said. ``You're talking about an absolutely drastic change in the models available to the public,'' McCarthy said. Station wagons and minivans popular with families could disappear from showrooms, he said. Bryan said automakers had equally dire warnings in the 1970s, but managed to meet the standards. Sens. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., and Don Nickles, R-Okla., will lead the opposition during debate, which could begin this week. Congressional sources said the bill was among several that Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, hoped to bring to the floor. Riegle served notice of a likely filibuster Friday by filing an objection to waiving the customary two-day waiting period before voting to halt debate.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Leaning Toward Old-Fashioned Conventional Weapons
DOC.TEXT: America's buildup in the Persian Gulf has given added impetus to proponents of a post-Cold War defense budget that favors old-fashioned conventional weapons over sophisticated strategic hardware. The House of Representatives takes up the fiscal 1991 defense bill Monday, working from a $283 billion blueprint drawn up prior to Iraq's Aug. 3 invasion of Kuwait. Deterring Iraqi aggression and its cost were not a direct consideration when the House Armed Services Committee drew up the plan. But some lawmakers say all the same that the measure is geared to equipping U.S. forces for a desert conflict rather than a European showdown. ``The bill better addresses these types of contingencies,'' said Rep. Dave McCurdy, D-Okla., a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee. The summit meeting between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev drove home what had already been seen as a diminished Soviet threat. Both leaders expressed confidence that the two superpowers could agree on a treaty to slash nuclear arms by the end of the year. Responding to improved climate before the Helsinki summit, the Armed Services bill slashed $24 billion from President Bush's original request of $307 billion for fiscal 1991. Among the budget targets were the B-2 stealth bomber, the Strategic Defense Initiative and two land-based nuclear missiles. Among the programs given a second chance were the M-1 tank, F-15 jet fighter and V-22 Osprey helicopter. The estimated $1 billion a month cost of Operation Desert Shield could change the amount eventually approved by the House. And any deficit reduction agreement between congressional and White House negotiators could do the same. A package covering some of the cost of Desert Shield will be presented to the Armed Services Committee on Wednesday and taken up by the full House the same day. Even if a so-called ``Iraqi add-on'' is adopted, the House bill will differ in detail from the legislation approved by the Senate last month. The Senate measure calls for $289 billion in defense spending and leaves intact Bush's request for the B-2 bomber. But it slashes $1 billion from his proposal for SDI. The ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee, Sen. John Warner of Virginia, said in an interview last week that $289 billion is the lowest the defense budget can go. ``Senator Nunn and I are firmly together. The Senate numbers on defense are the bare minimum,'' Warner said referring to the committee's chairman, Sam Nunn, D-Ga. The Senate adopted its defense bill shortly after Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait and many lawmakers cautioned against deep cuts in light of the events in the Middle East. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole of Kansas summed up the argument, saying Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has provided a ``wake-up call.'' The Senate reaction was duly noted by a liberal Democrat on the House Armed Services Committee, Rep. Patricia Schroeder of Colorado. ``I'm hoping that time and reflection won't allow that same stampede here,'' Schroeder said in an interview last week. Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, says the Iraqi aggression will temper the widespread calls for significant cuts in the defense budget but not prevent military reductions. ``I think it will slow it down somewhat but there will be cuts and we'll still look at the kind of strategic systems like the B-2, MX rail-garrison that we have proposed eliminating,'' Cohen said on returning from a congressional trip to the Middle East. The House Armed Services legislation would limit production of the B-2 stealth bomber to the 15 planes already under construction. The Air Force believes the radar-evading plane is ideal for locating targets in the Soviet Union, but lawmakers have winced at the bomber's cost of nearly $865 million per plane. The committee also stripped nearly $2 billion from Bush's request of $4.7 billion for the Strategic Defense Initiative, cut military personnel by 129,500 and scaled back on two nuclear missile programs. It also rejected Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's second attempt in two years to kill the V-22 Osprey, the tilt-rotor aircraft the Marine Corps envisions as a futuristic transport vehicle. The panel also added money for programs that the Defense Department and Bush did not want, coming under attack from some Republicans for pork-barrel spending. Among the additions are $150 million for M-1 tank modifications and $100 million for F-15 fighters. Some Democrats perceive those additions as necessary for a military that is more likely to face Iraq than the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Link to Moscow Has Weakened in Recent Years
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has been Iraq's main arms supplier for more than two decades, but Middle East experts say relations between Moscow and its Persian Gulf client cooled in recent years as Iraq looked to the West for technology. Moscow's decision to condemn the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait, and its support for United Nations economic sanctions against Baghdad, is a major blow to Saddam Hussein. But it's not the first sign of change in Iraqi-Soviet relations. ``It already was changing,'' said Robert Neumann, a former U.S. ambassador to Saudi Arabia and other Middle Eastern nations. Neumann said Iraq began turning toward the West, especially France, in the early 1980s. This followed Iraq's condemnation of the December 1979 Soviet invasion of predominantly Muslim Afghanistan and the start of Iraq's eight-year war with Iran. Iraq also has been irritated by Soviet support for Syria, an arch enemy of Iraq. Signs of the strained relationship were evident Sunday when Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Iraq was asking for trouble by refusing to withdraw from Kuwait. ``What the present Iraqi leadership is doing is driving it into a dead end, and I hope President Saddam Hussein will heed this appeal to him,'' Gorbachev told a news conference at the conclusion of his summit with President Bush in Helsinki, Finland. Moscow halted arms sales to Iraq after the invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Up to then it ranked as Baghdad's main arms supplier. Moscow sold Iraq $23 billion in weapons between 1982 and 1989, or about 55 percent of total Iraqi arms purchases in that period, according to the Congressional Research Service. Last year Iraq began building Soviet-designed T-72 main battle tanks which it previously had purchased directly from Moscow. The Soviets sold hundreds of the tanks to Iraq during the gulf war, and they were a key factor in a string of Iraqi military victories that forced Iran to accept a cease-fire that took effect in August 1988. Also in Iraq's arsenal are Soviet-made MiG-29 fighter jets, Sukhoi Su-24 and Su-25 fighter-bombers, and Tu-22 Blinder bombers. Iraq also has an undetermined number of Soviet-made SS-12 Scaleboard mobile ballistic missiles as well as shorter-range Scud-B missiles. Some American analysts believe Moscow is playing a ``double game'' of giving the appearance of cooperating with the West in trying to push Saddam out of Kuwait while at the same time preserving its relations with its longtime ally. ``The Soviet Union has provided Iraq with tangible and invaluable diplomatic support even as it seeks to promote the perception that Moscow is sorely chagrined with Saddam Hussein,'' said Frank J. Gaffney Jr., director of the Center for Security Policy, a Washington think tank. Gaffney said cooperation between Moscow and Baghdad also extends to intelligence gathering. ``It is only reasonable to presume that this cooperation now involves the provision to Baghdad of vital strategic warning and tactical information about the multinational force arrayed against Iraq _ a capability which Iraq basically lacks,'' he said Friday. On Thursday the Iraqi foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, said in Moscow after meeting with Gorbachev that he appreciated the Soviets' willingness to listen to his country's grievances even though Gorbachev still insisted Iraq withdraw from Kuwait. ``I without hesitation can still call the Soviets our friends despite the differences between us,'' Aziz told reporters. Saddam took a tougher tone on Saturday in a public message to Gorbachev and Bush on the eve of their Helsinki meeting. The Iraqi leader suggested the outcome of the meeting would determine whether Moscow was finished as a superpower. ``He who represents the Soviet Union should remember that doubts about the place of the Soviet Union as a superpower have gotten into the mind of every politician for some time, especially as the U.S. began to assume to be the sole power in the world,'' Saddam said. Soviet advisers in Iraq, estimated to number about 1,000, are believed to have helped train soldiers in the use and maintenance of Soviet-made weaponry. Gorbachev said Sunday that only 196 of those advisers were involved in military matters. He said their number had dropped to 150 and that all eventually would leave Iraq. Iraq began building relations with the Soviet Union after a 1958 coup that toppled the Iraqi monarchy and established a modern republic. In April 1972, Iraq signed a 20-year treaty of friendship and cooperation with Moscow. The pact called for cooperation in military, political, economic and social matters and was similar to a treaty the Soviets had with Egypt before President Anwar Sadat expelled thousands of Soviet advisers and repudiated the pact.

DOC.HEAD: Diver Attacked By Shark
DOC.TEXT: A shark grabbed a diver by his head but was driven off when the man smacked it several times with his spear gun, according to deputies. ``It picked him up, then just let go and sank back down,'' Bill Davenport said after his diving partner, Rodney Orr was attacked Saturday. Orr, 49, of Santa Rosa was able to reach his dive board and paddle for 20 minutes back to shore. He was treated for cuts on his nose, cheek and neck. The two were diving for abalone in about 40 feet of water in the ocean north of here. Orr told Sonoma County deputies he was on the surface when he was struck from behind. ``He was lucky,'' said Davenport. ``It was most likely a great white, from the size of it, from the size of the teeth marks.'' Orr said the shark's head measured between 18 inches and two feet across.

DOC.HEAD: Modern Arctic Country Stages Summit in a Week
DOC.TEXT: High-tech Finland, a model of efficiency and electronic knowhow, was an ideal choice to stage a complicated superpower summit on a week's notice. ``There wasn't much time ... but we can handle it,'' President Mauno Koivisto said calmly a few days before the sudden summit meeting between Presidents Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev. And he was right, though Bush and Gorbachev struggled at times with the sound system at their end-of-summit news conference. ``We have had a lot of big events _ not as big as this of course _ so we were confident we would be able to build this in such a short time,'' said Christer Hagglund, who supervised installation of telephones, electric typewriters, computer terminals and transmission facilities for 2,160 journalists from all over the world. ``Our telephone network is very efficient,'' he said. One radio journalist from Washington agreed. ``Is this a cellular phone? This town has the greatest toys,'' he exclaimed, holding a tiny, lightweight mobile telephone that isn't available in the United States yet. The Finnish company Nokia produces 14 per cent of the world's cellular phones, the largest share of any company in the world. Gorbachev was astounded by a Nokia product during his state visit to Helsinki last October. He was handed one of the six-inch-long phones with a short aerial and told to listen. Someone he knew in Moscow spoke to him through the phone and photographers registered Gorbachev's disbelief. Finnish technology has also produced thermal suits which protect humans at sub-zero temperatures; the artificial sweetener, Xylitol; the antiviral protein, interferon, and a five-year contraceptive coil without the adverse side effects of other intrauterine devices. While a few Lapps in the north still live a nomadic life, using reindeer for meat, for clothing and for bearing their belongings, most Finns are city dwellers in the south and the nation boasts one of the world's highest standards of living. The national school system reaches the Lapps, too, and Finland claims nearly 100 per cent of its population can read and write. At least 17 percent of the government's budget is allocated to education, science research and culture. Including funds from private industry, more than half of all Finnish research money goes to technology. Sixty percent of all working icebreakers were made in Finland, where one-third of the land mass is above the Arctic Circle. The country has over 100,000 lakes and its Finnish name, ``Suomi,'' is believed to be based on the word for ``swamp.'' Finland is a particular leader in forestry and agricultural developments. More than half its 135,200 square miles are covered with forest. Metal and forest products are Finland's main exports, and it is the world's second largest exporter of paper. Although Finns have all the modern conveniences, the latest technology and styles, they pay a lot for it. The modern railroad, highway and telephone networks are expensive to maintain because of the great distances involved, even though 60 per cent of the 5 million people live in urban areas. The low population, representing a small market for mass-produced products, makes prices higher. Cars are taxed at 130 per cent of their value to justify the cost in foreign currency of getting them and their parts to consumers. A radio priced at the equivalent of $600 in Helsinki could be bought for $100 at a discount warehouse in New York. Finns also pay high taxes, from 30 percent to 60 percent of their income, and 17 percent in sales taxes.

DOC.HEAD: Midwest Market Basket Holds More Than Corn and Soybeans
DOC.TEXT: California cuisine leave you longing? Your taste for Cajun cooking on the wane? An ambitious band of gourmet farmers and restaurateurs may have the answer for your tired taste buds: ``heartland haute cuisine.'' The nation's breadbasket is out to prove at the grocery and in the best restaurants that Midwest means a whole lot more than corn and soybeans. At the second annual ``Best of the Midwest Market'' on Sunday, more than 60 of gourmet food purveyors from 10 states strutted their stuff: wild forest gypsy mushrooms from Michigan, Illinois buffalo summer sausage, Nebraska blue corn, wine from Michigan, Illinois caviar and local blue-veined goat cheese. ``We don't have to borrow it from the West Coast, the East Coast or Europe,'' says Jim Eschner, who produces about 1,000 cases of Reisling, Chardonnay and Gewurztraminer wine each year at Winegrow Inc. in Buchanan, Mich. ``It's kind of neat _ Midwesterners have got their own identity.'' Winegrow's wine is served at Chicago's Printer's Row restaurant, where chef Michael Foley was among the first to tout Midwestern cuisine. ``We have all sorts of local fish, great games, unbelievable fruits and berries,'' said Foley. ``We are the stable breadbasket of the nation.'' ``Nobody's apologizing anymore for being Midwest,'' Linda Griffith, co-author of the newly published ``The Best of the Midwest'' cookbook, said in an interview Friday. Organizers of the Best of the Midwest Market say interest in heartland haute is growing. But it may still take some time for regional specialties to reach supermarket shelves. ``The majority of the market's foods cannot be found anywhere in Chicago,'' said Jill Van Cleave, co-chairman of the event sponsored by the Chicago chapter of the American Institute of Wine and Food. ``This is a major concern of ours _ to get the marketplace up to a better level,'' she said. Many of the participants run small cottage industries that do their own growing and marketing, cutting out the middleman. The farmer's market, they say, gives them a chance to showcase their products to a broader audience. ``It's a network,'' said Mary Galle, sales director of American Spoon Foods of Petoskey, Mich. ``The real important thing is ... the quality of both the product that we have and the service that we give.'' American Spoon Foods expects this year to sell 300,000 jars of its gourmet preserves, made from Michigan blueberries, thimbleberries and other fruits. Most sales are to restaurants and gourmet food shops, said Galle. Restaurants like Cousins Heritage Inn in Dexter, Mich., and River Wildlife, a private dinner club in Kohler, Wis., say they buy nearly all of their food from within the region. ``We don't go out of Wisconsin to get anything _ unless it's Norwegian salmon,'' said River Wildlife chef Sandy Wassink.

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush, Raisa Gorbachev Leaf Through History Books
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush and Raisa Gorbachev leafed through the pages of history in Finland's national library on Sunday, and said they were optimistic their husbands would find a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. The U.S. and Soviet first ladies, touring the Helsinki University Library, pored over ancient books, manuscripts, and maps, including the oldest known Moscow city map and an early American map showing California as an island. Mrs. Bush wore a royal blue dress, while Mrs. Gorbachev was wearing a severe gray suit and a violet blouse, appearing less stylish than she has on previous visits to the West. She has drawn criticism in the Soviet Union for her fashionable attire. Librarian Esko Hakli escorted the women through the domed, neoclassical library, pointing out the rarest of its 3 million books and 2 million other documents. Mrs. Gorbachev, a former university professor, repeatedly prodded him for historical tidbits as they strolled past stack upon stack of books, including the most complete collection of Russian works in Western Europe. She urged Mrs. Bush to prepare for a visit to Moscow by studying the 1538 map, although Hakli told reporters it shows only the Moscow River and a few other details ``and you wouldn't find your way with the help of that map.'' Mrs. Gorbachev corrected Halki when he pointed to ``Asiatic Russia'' on a map, saying of her ethnically diverse homeland, ``We are one Russia, not Asian Russia and European Russia.'' Helsinki University Library, as Finland's national library, receives copies of all books published in the country, including one of the first Finnish language books, a religious primer printed in the mid-1500s. ``Is it a Bible?'' Mrs. Gorbachev asked in English. From 1820 to 1917, when Finland was a province of Czarist Russia, the library also had the right to a copy of all books published by Russian printers, and now has more than 400,000 works in Russian. The buff and white building also houses manuscripts of Finnish composers, including the first draft of Jean Sibelius' violin concerto and the score of his 5th symphony. The university was founded in 1640 in Turku, the former capital of Finland, but a fire destroyed the entire city in 1827 and the university was moved to Helsinki. Only 800 of the library's 40,000 volumes were rescued. Russian Czar Nicholas I took a personal interest in rebuilding the library, and the floor plan is arranged in the shape of his monogram. Mrs. Gorbachev and Mrs. Bush, looking relaxed after morning tea with Finnish President Mauno Koivisto's wife Tellervo, told reporters they expected their husbands would have a successful summit. ``Yes, there is a peaceful solution,'' to the Persian Gulf crisis, Mrs. Bush said. ``Otherwise we wouldn't be here.'' ``I hope our husbands, along with the rest of the free world, will work hard to make peace,'' she said. Mrs. Gorbachev added that ``as people, as citizens of our countries,'' the first ladies wanted ``a political, peaceful solution to be found.'' Asked whether she was worried about American soldiers sent to Saudi Arabia, Mrs. Bush said: ``Of course we worry about the men and the women. We worry.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting a0721 to fix hyphen in slugline.
DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Former President Gerald R. Ford's boyhood home that has stood empty for nearly 20 years will be sold because efforts failed to turn it into a museum. ``It's almost a lost cause,'' said Steele Taylor, chairman of the Grand Rapids Arts and Museum Commission. ``We can't get anybody interested in fixing it up.'' The federal Veterans Administration acquired the four-bedroom house in 1972 when the owner defaulted. Three years later, after Ford became president, the VA donated it to the city. The commission had trouble raising the estimated $51,000 to renovate the home into a museum because Ford lived in at least eight homes in Grand Rapids, said Jim Kratsas, curator of the Gerald R. Ford Museum. City records show Ford lived in the white two-story house from 1923 to 1930, from the time he was 10 years old through his junior year at the Grand Rapids South High School. In a 1989 letter to museum director Timothy Chester, Ford wrote: ``I have no objection to _ in fact, I endorse the sale.'' Museum officials have asked the city's Historic Preservation Commission to designate the house as a historic landmark to protect it from demolition. Helena Jones, 86, who has lived next door to the Ford house for 20 years, said sentimentality aside, she hopes the house gets sold. ``He wasn't president that long,'' Jones said. ``We've got enough things named after Ford.''

Former CBS anchorman Walter Cronkite says he has something in common with every ``red-blooded human being'' _ a fascination with dinosaurs. Cronkite was doing his part last week to publicize the great beasts of the past, spending time in Montana to film a documentary series on dinosaurs. ``It's a fascinating project,'' he said Friday as an international crew filmed a segment northwest of Great Falls, Mont. ``It's something that I think will make an impact in America.'' The four-hour series produced by Canadian, British and German television will be shown in the United States on the Arts and Entertainment cable channel about a year from now. Cronkite, 73, spoke with owners of the Bynum Rock Shop, who found the bones of baby dinosaurs that led to discovery of a key fossil site. The crew also has filmed a fossil dig near Circle, Mont., where the most complete skeleton of a Tyrannosaurus rex was discovered two years ago.

Actor Tony Randall will be the master of ceremonies and violinists Itzhak Perlman and Pinchas Zukerman will perform duets at an concert to wrap up a campaign to raise money for the arts. The Oct. 31 performance is to celebrate the official end of ``Trilogy: A Campaign for the Arts,'' a $25 million campaign to support Columbus' three major arts institutions. The Columbus Symphony Orchestra will receive $12.5 million of the money raised; the Columbus Museum of Art will receive $6 million. The Columbus Association for the Performing Arts, which owns and operates the Ohio and the Palace theaters, will receive $6 million to pay off the Ohio Theatre expansion. ``The concert will be a celebration and a fund-raising campaign at the same time,'' said Doug Kridler, president of the Columbus Association for the Performing Arts. ``Obviously, we already have a lot to celebrate by having gotten this far, and we have a lot of people to thank for helping get it there.''

Lou Diamond Phillips' latest role is causing controversy among Navajos, but South Dakota Sioux are honoring the multiracial actor for his portrayals of American Indians. The Sioux have given Phillips, 28, star of the 1987 film ``La Bamba,'' the honorary name ``Starkeeper,'' publicist Eddie Michaels said Friday. The tribe will officially confer the name on Phillips at a ceremony later this year in the Black Hills of South Dakota, Michaels said. The watchdog group the American Indian Registry for the Performing Arts has challenged the casting of Phillips as a Navajo policeman in a film based on author Tony Hillerman's novel ``The Dark Wind.'' Phillips, who played a Mexican-Indian in ``Young Guns'' and ``Young Guns II,'' has said he is part Cherokee, Filipino, Scottish-Irish, Hawaiian and Hispanic. Bonnie Paradise, director of the American Indian Registry, said last week that Phillips had not provided documentation of his lineage.

DOC.HEAD: Warring Cambodian Factions Said Ready To Accept U.N. Peace Plan
LaserPhoto JAK2
DOC.TEXT: The four warring factions in Cambodia appear ready to accept a U.N. peace plan to end their 11-year-old war, Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas said Sunday. ``We are encouraged by the fact that the four factions have indicated they can accept the document as the basis for settling the Cambodian conflict,'' the foreign minister said after the opening session of peace talks in the Indonesian capital. Alatas said ``the circumstances for achieving a comprehensive settlement are unlikely ever again to be as favorable as they are now.'' The guerrillas and Cambodia's Vietnam-backed government had no immediate comment. The talks, originally scheduled to open Wednesday, were delayed because key leaders threatened to stay away unless their counterparts attended. The talks were focusing on a plan backed by the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council _ the United States, Soviet Union, China, Britain and France _ to end Cambodia's civil war. The plan envisions the formation of a transitional council on which each of the four Cambodian factions would be represented. The so-called Supreme National Council would cede much of its authority to the United Nations, whose representatives would administer the country until free elections could be held. The plan also calls for disarming and regrouping the four armies. Earlier meetings in Indonesia and elsewhere since July 1988 ended inconclusively when the four factions disagreed on how to share power in the period before elections. Premier Hun Sen of the Vietnam-installed government in Phnom Penh has accepted the U.N. plan ``not only as the agenda of the meeting, but also as the framework of the solution.'' The three-party guerrilla resistance coalition also accepts the U.N. proposal. It was represented Sunday by Khieu Samphan, nominal leader of the communist Khmer Rouge; former Cambodian Premier Son Sann, who heads the anti-communist Khmer People's National Liberation Front; and Prince Norodom Ranariddh, who represents the faction of his father, Prince Norodom Sihanouk. He said he was ill and could not attend. The Indonesian foreign minister and a French Foreign Ministry official, Edwige Avice, were leading the talks. ``The main idea for us, for the permanent five, is an enhanced intervention of the United Nations in order to create a neutral political environment allowing the Cambodian people to decide freely on its future by free and fair elections,'' Ms. Avice said. Sihanouk has said the guerrilla coalition would allow the Phnom Penh government half the seats on the proposed 12-member council, with the other six seats to be divided equally among the three guerrilla groups. However, he said the council's decisions should be made by consensus rather than majority vote. He also said the council should be formed before the start of the U.N. General Assembly session later this month so its representative could take Cambodia's seat in the world body, which is now held by the guerrilla coalition. He said China supported his proposals. The guerrilla coalition's non-Communist resistance forces are backed by Washington. China backs the Khmer Rouge. The guerrilla coalition is battling the government Vietnam installed in Phnom Penh after it invaded in late 1978 and toppled the Khmer Rouge, who had during their nearly four-year rule tried to transform Cambodia into a radical agrarian society. Their program resulted in the deaths of nearly 1 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Shot to Death at Comedian Tom Smothers' Ranch While He Was Away
DOC.TEXT: A man killed his sister and wounded a cousin in a shooting at a vineyard-girded estate owned by comedian Tom Smothers, who was away at the time, deputies said. Less than an hour after Saturday's shooting, a man identified as Gustavo Pureco, 25, of Santa Rosa surrendered at the Sonoma County jail and was booked on suspicion of murder and attempted murder. Sheriff's authorities said Pureco apparently was angry because his sister, 18-year-old Eva Pureco, had recently moved out of his house and had gone to live with other relatives at Smothers' 25-acre hilltop Remick Ridge estate. The woman was shot twice in the chest with a .45-caliber pistol, said sheriff's Sgt. Chuck Laver. The cousin, Ismael Calderon, was in critical condition Sunday at Sonoma County Community Hospital, said nursing supervisor Kathy Kuhne. Smothers said Miss Pureco was not one of his employees, but he has known Calderon for many years. ``This was one of our loyal workers,'' he said. ``I've had this ranch 18 years and he's been here 15 or 16.'' Smothers planted the vineyard in the 1970s to supply grapes for his brother Dick's former winery in Santa Cruz. Dick Smothers has since gotten out of the winery business.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Guerrillas Battle Abu Nidal Fighters In Tunnels
DOC.TEXT: PLO forces claimed victory Sunday in their battle for control of refugee camps in south Lebanon after storming fortified tunnels holding the remnants of troops loyal to terrorist leader Abu Nidal. Police report at least 75 people killed and more than 200 wounded during the Palestine Liberation Organization's three-day offensive to oust Abu Nidal guerrillas from Sidon and nearby refugee camps. ``We have established undisputed control over all the refugee camps in Sidon and the rest of south Lebanon,'' Younis Awad, a senior aide to PLO chairman Yasser Arafat, said in the Ein el-Hilweh shantytown, site of the 12-hour battle in the tunnels. Awad said most of the 300 fighters from Abu Nidal's Fatah-Revolutionary Council were either killed or captured in the camp on the outskirts of Sidon, a port city about 25 miles south of Beirut. The two sides fought in hand-to-hand combat in the refugee camp, Lebanon's largest with an estimated 32,000 people. ``They're finished,'' Awad said. ``It's a final victory.'' During the fighting, Abu Nidal forces in the nearby hilltop village od Majdalyoun unleashed a 30-minute artillery barrage on Ein el-Hilweh. Thousands of refugees fled the camp at the height of the fighting. Many of those killed in the latest battles were civilians. Police reported about 100 Abu Nidal fighters remained holed up in Majdalyoun, a main training base and weapons depot for Abu Nidal's group. The village is about five miles east of Sidon. ``It's a fortress up there. It will take the PLO quite a while to get them out,'' said a police spokesman who cannot be identified under briefing regulations. Abu Nidal, whose real name is Sabri al-Banna, broke away from the PLO in 1973 and was sentenced to death in absentia by a PLO tribunal for killing Arafat aides. Abu Nidal's group has been torn by internal feuds in recent months. Scores of men have been killed and some of Abu Nidal's top aides defected with their followers. Abu Nidal is sought by the United States and some Western European nations for terrorist attacks over the last 15 years, including massacres at the Rome and Vienna airports in December 1985 that killed a total of 20 people. He is also wanted in connection with the hijacking of a Pan American World Airways jet in Karachi, Pakistan, in September 1986. Twenty passengers were killed and 120 wounded. Security sources say Abu Nidal's faction has increasingly been allied with the Syrians, who have about 40,000 troops in Lebanon. Police officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, predict that the PLO victory in south Lebanon could trigger retaliation by Abu Nidal loyalists. ``We're going to see a wave of assassinations, bombings and kidnappings against Arafat's men,'' one official commented. Arafat reportedly has about 5,000 guerrillas in south Lebanon. In Sidon, a general strike was called Sunday to protest the violence. The city of 350,000 people has been ravaged by fires following heavy shelling.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Wins Hints of Aid, Says Soviets Can't Be Bought
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail Gorbachev won hints of more economic aid from President Bush on Sunday but rebuffed suggestions that Moscow would play a global second fiddle to Washington. ``It would be very oversimplified and very superficial to judge that the Soviet Union could be bought for dollars,'' Gorbachev told a joint news conference with the U.S. president at the close of their one-day summit. The Soviet and U.S. leaders pledged to work closely in using commercial and diplomatic pressure to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, but Gorbachev stressed he was not following the U.S. lead in order to win American aid. ``We do not want to get caught up in a debate about prestige,'' he said when asked to respond to Iraq leader Saddam Hussein's challenge for Moscow to defy U.S. will in the Middle East in order to prove that it was still a superpower. ``No single country, however powerful, will be able to provide the leadership which individual countries formerly tried to provide, including some countries which are represented here,'' he said. Gorbachev and his entourage departed for Moscow Sunday night. During the seven hours of summit talks, the Soviet leader again balked at sending troops or warships to bolster U.S. forces implementing a United Nations embargo against Iraq. Gorbachev won a pledge from Bush that U.S. troops would withdraw from the Arabian peninsula at the close of the crisis. And the Soviet leader announced that about 150 Soviet military experts remained in Iraq, down from 196 at the beginning of the crisis. ``They are leaving Iraq and the process is moving forward, so I don't think it's a problem,'' he said. There had been speculation he might agree to withdraw all the experts. Bush said the presence of the advisers was ``not a major irritant,'' but that there removal would ``facilitate'' understanding in the United States of the Soviet position. Bush said that he had asked Gorbachev neither to send a special message to Hussein _ a former Soviet client _ nor to dispatch troops or naval vessels to join U.S. forces implementing U.S. sanctions against Iraq. ``I did not ask him to send troops in,'' Bush said. ``If the Soviet Union wants to send troops in at the invitation of the Saudis, that would be fine with me.'' Gorbachev stressed his desire for a political rather than a military solution to the crisis, and Bush acknowledged that ``some differences remain'' in the advisability of using force. Bush did not spell out any concrete steps the U.S. government might take to prop up the failing economy of the Soviet Union, where shortages of bread and other staples were spreading. But the U.S. president did he say he wanted to bolster radical reform policies that are now under debate in the Soviet Union. ``We, for course, want perestroika to succeed,'' Bush said. ``I think that this remarkable cooperation that has been demonstrated by the Soviet Union at the United Nations gets me inclined to recommend as close cooperation in the economic field as possible, and I will be saying this to the Congress when I get back,'' he said. Bush and key members of the Senate say they will push for ratification of a bilateral trade agreement and favorable tariffs for the Soviet Union once that nation's parliament codifies recent liberalizations in emigration policy. Bush also noted that he was sending Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher to Moscow this week with a team of U.S. businessmen to ``encourage economic cooperation in as many ways as possible.'' White House chief of staff John Sununu told reporters that the two leaders discussed cooperation in developing energy resources, but he did not go as far as Bush did on Saturday, saying he might be willing to trade U.S. technology for Soviet oil. The Soviet Union is the world's largest oil producer.
